notes.title: Sabk (Style) Overview: Khorasani, Iraqi, Hindi
notes.content: Understand the historical shifts in Persian poetics from the early epic/straightforward diction (Khorasani) to refined mystical/lyrical expression (Iraqi) and later intricate imagery and intellectual conceit (Hindi). Link these to dynastic/courtly shifts and Indo-Persian patronage.
keyTakeaways: Khorasani: clarity, epic tone; early courts (Ghaznavids, Seljuqs).
Iraqi: Sufi lyricism; Saʿdi, Hafez peak ghazal polish.
Hindi (sabk-e hindī): complex metaphors, intellectualism; Mughal India.

resources.title: Browne — A Literary History of Persia (Vols.)

notes.title: Ferdowsi & the Shahnameh
notes.content: Epic foundation text; national mytho-history; language revival. Know composition date, scope (~50–60k distichs), sources (Khwadāy-Nāmag), and its influence on later romance epics.
keyTakeaways: Completed ~1010 CE; cornerstone of New Persian.
Themes: heroism, kingship, moral order (farr).
Influence on Nezami's romantic masnavis and visual arts.

notes.title: Nezami's Khamsa (Five Treasures)
notes.content: Master of narrative mathnavi; five long poems blending ethics, romance, and politics. Frequently compared/imitated by later poets (e.g., Amir Khusrau).
keyTakeaways: Core works: Makhzan-al-Asrār, Khosrow o Shirin, Leyli o Majnun, Haft Peykar, Eskandar-Nāmeh.
Blueprint for Persian romance & courtly ethos.
Iconic for manuscript illustration traditions.

resources.title: World History Encyclopedia — Khamsa of Nizami

notes.title: Jami's Haft Awrang (Seven Thrones)
notes.content: Late-classical synthesis across didactic and romantic masnavis; core texts like Yūsuf o Zulaykhā are standard exam references.
keyTakeaways: Seven masnavis combining ethics, mysticism, romance.
Extensively illustrated under Safavids/Timurids.
Bridges classical canon to early modern tastes.

notes.title: Saʿdi's Golestan (Structure & Themes)
notes.content: Eight-chapter prose-poetry classic; ethics, statecraft, education, social mores. Frequent translation/summary tasks appear in papers.
keyTakeaways: Golestan has 8 chapters after the introduction.
Style: moral anecdotes + embedded verse.
Pairs with Būstān for didactic corpus.

notes.title: Rumi's Divan-e Shams & the Ghazal Zenith
notes.content: High Sufi lyricism; trance-like ecstatic diction; key for theme & imagery questions. Know difference between Masnavi-ye Maʿnavi and Divan-e Shams.
keyTakeaways: Divan contains thousands of ghazals; dedicated to Shams.
Exam angles: love, divine longing, paradox, intoxication.
Influence on Iqbal & later Persianate traditions.

resources.title: Book — Selected Poems, Divan-e Shams (English tr.)

notes.title: Nima Yushij & She'r-e Nima'i (Modern Free-Verse)
notes.content: Pivot to modern Persian poetry; flexible meter, colloquial diction, new imagery. Foundational for Sepehri, Forugh, Akhavan-Sales, Shamlu.
keyTakeaways: Manifesto poem: "Afsāneh".
Break from classical metrics; narrative/visual modernity.
Anchor for questions on modernist poetics.

resources.title: Tehran Times — Yushij 'Father of modern Persian poetry'

notes.title: Indo-Persian Literature in South Asia
notes.content: Massive Persian output in the subcontinent (Delhi, Deccan, Mughal courts); sabk-e hindī; translations & histories; links to Urdu literary evolution.
keyTakeaways: Indo-Persian corpus exceeds Iran's output in some periods.
Patronage systems shaped style & themes.
Essential for Pakistan-context questions.

resources.title: Encyclopaedia Iranica — Persian Literature in India

notes.title: Language Stages & Scripts: Old, Middle, New Persian
notes.content: Map epigraphic/linguistic stages (Achaemenid Old Persian → Sasanian Middle Persian/Pahlavi → New Persian); scripts and key corpora.
keyTakeaways: Only Persian attested in all three chronological stages.
Pahlavi literature preserves Sasanian-era material.
Exam tasks often ask brief definitional contrasts.

notes.title: Grammar Essentials for Composition & Translation
notes.content: Target exam-relevant points: ezāfe, direct object marker (rā), demonstratives vs. adjectives, verb transitivity, common compound verbs.
keyTakeaways: Master ezāfe chains in prose translation.
Track rā for definitive/direct objects.
Practice verb paradigms for past/past-perfect.

notes.title: Translation (English → Persian) Practice Sets
notes.content: Art/architecture/history passages are common. Build a bank of cultural-lexicon equivalents and syntactic reshaping techniques (nominalization, relative clauses).
keyTakeaways: Retain semantic density; avoid word-for-word calque.
Prefer Persian idiom; watch register & cohesion.
Keep term glossaries (e.g., illumination/tazhib).

notes.title: Iqbal & Rumi: Influence Mapping (Essay Topic)
notes.content: Trace Rumi's metaphysics, love, self-annihilation/baqā, and didactic method into Iqbal's reconstruction (khudi, action, prophetic vitality). Use textual pairings.
keyTakeaways: Validate with Jāvid-Nāma & Rumi intertexts.
Cite Iqbal's Persian works (Zabūr-e ʿAjam, Asrār-e Khudi).
Contrast mystical quietism vs. Iqbalian activism.

notes.title: MCQ Staples & Quick Facts
notes.content: High-yield facts often asked in Part-I MCQs: founder of modern Persian short story, Golestan chapters, founders of modern poetry, earliest mystical mathnavi influences, etc.
keyTakeaways: Golestan has 8 chapters.
Jamalzadeh = pioneer of Persian short story.
Nima Yushij = father of modern Persian poetry/free-verse school.

notes.title: Digital Libraries & Sourcing Primary Texts
notes.content: Use reputable online repositories for original verses, critical editions, and bilingual aids to support quotations and translations.
keyTakeaways: Ganjoor: authoritative open archive for classical poets.
Browne's 'Literary History': canonical historical survey.
University guides aggregate grammar & readings.
